listitem.para: An HTTP method that should delete a resource.
An HTTP method that should return a representation of a resource.
An HTTP method very similar to a GET except that it only returns the headers associated with the GET and not the actual representation.
A characteristic of being able to be performed multiple times with the same result. HTTP GET, PUT, DELETE, and HEAD are meant to be idempotent while POST is not.

Safe methods do not change the state of the resource. Unsafe methods are known to change the state of the resource. HTTP GET and HEAD are suppose to be safe. HTTP PUT, POST, and DELETE are suppose to be unsafe.
An HTTP method that will list the methods implemented by the server and available for a specific resource.
An HTTP method that should set the representation of a resource -- including create in cases where the full identity is known by the client ahead of time.
An HTTP method that can create resources and perform opaque actions on resources.
An encapsulation of information (e.g., state) encoded using a format (e.g. XML, JSON, HTML).
Anything that can be identified by a URI. A resource can have multiple representations.

Uniform Resource Identifier - Identifies a name or resource. URIs can be absolute (e.g.,http://myorg.org/readme.html) or relative (e.g., /readme.html) path. URIs are more general than a URL. Not all URIs are URLs.
Uniform Resource Locator - Identifies how to find a resource (e.g., http://myorg.org/book/isbn/12345/pdf). All URLs are also URIs.
Uniform Resource Name - Identifies a resource's name (e.g., urn:isbn:12345)
